title: Who will win the World Series?
preds: Cubs are 78-1 this season when leading by 4 runs.

Cubs still need two in a row. Tough
40% chance of winning each game gives them a 6% chance of a comeback. A 50% gives them a 12.5% chance. I'll split the difference at about 8.
Winning three in a row is just phenomenally unlikely.
Home advantage is slight and winning 3 in a row is unlikely.

Only five teams could accomplish the 3-1 comeback in World Series history. 1925 Pittsburgh Pirates 
1958 New York Yankees
1968 Detroit Tigers
1979 Pittsburgh Pirates
1985 Kansas City Royals
Simple odds of the various outcomes.
If each game is considered 50/50 then i make odds of cubs win 1/9 or 11%. My maths is wrong! Should be 1/8 or 87.5%!! Thanks @Raahul_Kumar
Cleveland have to win just one out of the remaining three, and two of those games are at home. 538 gives Chicago a 15% chance.

In coin-flip terms, what are the Cubs' chances of coming back? Assume these two teams are evenly matched and thus each has a 50 percent chance of winning a given game. That means the Cubs' "side of the coin" is going to have to come up three straight times. Simple probability tells you there's a 12.5 percent chance of that happening. There's your quick and dirty guide to the Cubs' chances of upsetting the Indians in the 2016 World Series.
How many teams have won best-of-seven postseason series after being down 3-1? Not counting this year's Cubs, 81 teams have fallen behind 3-1 in a best-of-seven playoff series. Of those 81 teams, 12 have come back to win the series in question -- five times in World Series play. Overall, that means 14.8 percent team of teams in the Cubs' position have pulled off the comeback. At this point, you'll note that history is a bit kinder to such teams than is the coin-flip model.  http://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/indians-cubs-2016-world-series-what-mlb-history-says-about-teams-down-3-games-to-1/ Taking the higher of the two estimates and factoring in consensus, CI will almost certaintly beat the Cubs.

Cubs have never won a World Series since moving to Wrigleyville, 100 years ago.
The last two wins for the Cubs were 1907 and 1908, when the team played at Taylor and Wolcott, south of Madison, are generally considered to be the "South Side" Chicago championships.  --- Various curses, the Billy Goat, Bartman, Wrigleyville, et al, seem to be compounding the negative vibes for the North Side Cubs.

In 2016 the AL continued to dominate the NL in interleague play, winning 163 and losing 127.  
Even more sobering is that the AL won 81 and lost 59 in NL stadiums, without the DH !
http://www.vegasinsider.com/mlb/stats/interleague/
Cleveland has home field and took game 1. Hard to favor Toronto over them in this situation.

As a quick and dirty method, I have been looking at runs-scored ratios, in case anybody cares.  A team that on average scores a lot more runs than its opponents is probably a better bet over an extended period.  As of yesterday, Cleveland is undefeated in the post-season and has scored 2.43 runs for every opponent's run; Toronto is at .800 in the post-season and scores almost two runs per opponent's run.  The Cubs, at .750, score a bit over 1.25 runs for each run scored by an opponent; LA is at .600, and actually scores fewer runs on average than its opponents, about .86.  Of course Toronto can't play Cleveland in the Series, but either of them seems at the moment a better bet than either NL team.  Alas, this method requires me to keep track of scores pretty much every day, which means I am often staying up well past my bedtime.  This has doubtless clouded my judgment in other matters besides this one.

Given the records and face-to-face competition through the year, the Cubs and the Rangers are best positioned to compete in the World Series.  The Dodgers have an outside chance but lack the depth in their pitching staff to overcome the Cubs.
Chicago Cubs and Boston Red Sox have greatest depth in all categories and Epstein has created both teams...a genius

Wildcard in AL is most likely going to be Toronto, which gives East an additional team.  Wildcard in NL is up for grabs, but Cubs are best team in NL and have everything needed for playoff baseball.  However, baseball has random teams win in playoffs regularly, so probability needs to be spread to account for that.
I used the ELO scores for the teams, and gave a little more weight to the divisions sending more teams through wild cards--seems to cut the risk a bit. I'll need to adjust this later.
Based on implicit odds from betting websites
Detroit Tigers are hot going into the finals as are Boston.  One of these two could handle anything coming out of the Natonal League.
Odds adjusted to account for ridiculous poor base rate on a certain NL Central Team over the past 100 years. The 4% I give that division is for the Cardinals.

Based on:
1) 52 AL / 48 NL split based on interleague, all-star, and recent WS history.
2) rough odds of the number of team to make playoffs from each division.
